TemplateInfo.Name: Summary Statistics - Default
TemplateInfo.Title: Summary Statistics - Default
TemplateInfo.Subtitle: Results for [baseSysPretty]
TemplateInfo.GeneralDescription:
Income concepts:

Market/Original incomes are the sum of (gross) income from employment and self-employment plus income from other sources. Other sources include income from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16, minus private transfers paid to other households. See income list ils_origy in the country models.

Disposable incomes are the sum of market incomes and benefits (incl. pensions) minus direct taxes and social insurance contributions. See income list ils_dispy in the country models. Equivalised disposable income in the next row is the total disposable household income divided by the modified OECD scale to take differences in household composition into account. The modified OECD scale attributes a weight of 1 to the head of the household, a weight of 0.5 to every person above the age of 14 and a weight of 0.3 to every child aged 0-14.

Decile groups are calculated by ranking individuals according to their equivalised disposable household income and dividing them into ten similar-sized groups.

All monetary amounts – except for the fiscal overview – are presented in average monthly amounts and in the currency defined in the Euromod output file.

Poverty indicators:

Households are defined as being at risk of poverty (poor) if their equivalised disposable household income is below the poverty line. The poverty line is defined as 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income. The poverty gap is the difference between the poverty line and the median income of people at-risk-of poverty divided by the poverty line. The median income of people at-risk-of poverty is based on equivalised disposable income.

NOTE: negative disposable household incomes are recoded to 0 for all poverty related results.

Inequality indicators:

Gini measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

The S80/20 ratio - also referred to as the income quintile share ratio – is the ratio of the total income received by the 20% of the population with the highest income to that received by the bottom 20%.

NOTE: negative household incomes are recoded to 0 for results on Gini and S80/20 indicators.

Page.Name: FiscalOverview
Page.Title: Market Incomes and Government Revenue && Expenditure
Page.Subtitle: Yearly, mill., currency as defined in EM output
Page.Description:
The table shows total annual amounts of the specified tax-benefit system(s). It provides an overview of market incomes as well as government revenue and expenditure covered in EUROMOD.

The aggregated amount for “other social insurance contributions” is already included in “employee social insurance contributions” in all EM versions released before 2018.

Results refer to the following income lists:

  • Total market incomes: ils_origy
  • Income from (self) employment: ils_earns
  • Other market incomes: ils_origy minus ils_earns
  • Government revenue through taxes and social insurance contributions are the sum of:
    • Direct taxes: ils_tax
    • Employee social insurance contributions: ils_sicee
    • Self-employed social insurance contributions: ils_sicse
    • Other social insurance contributions: ils_sicot
    • Employer social insurance contributions (not part of disposable income): ils_sicer
  • Credited social insurance contributions (not part of disposable income): ils_sicct
  • Government expenditure on social transfers: ils_ben
    Which is the sum of:
    • Unemployment benefits: ils_b1_bun
    • Family and education benefits: ils_b2_bfaed
    • Social assistance and housing benefits: ils_b2_bsaho
    • Pensions, health and disability benefits: ils_b2_penhl

    As well as the sum of:
    • Means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_benmt
    • Non-means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_bennt
    • Pensions: ils_pen

Row.Name: Government revenue through taxes and social insurance contributions
... employer social insurance contributions (not part of disposable income)
Credited social insurance contributions (not part of disposable income)

Table.Title: 2.1.a Mean household income by decile groups and income components
Table.Description:
The table shows the mean household income disaggregated by decile groups and income components. The last two columns show to what extent benefits and taxes are simulated in Euromod (rather than taken from the inputdata), expressed as the share of simulated benefits/taxes of all benefits/taxes. The last two rows show the mean income of the total population (All) and the population at-risk-of-poverty (Poor).

While the calculation of the decile groups is based on equivalised income, the reported mean incomes refer to non-equivalised household results.

Column.Name:
Disposable
Income
Column.Tooltip: Original income + Benefits (incl. Public Pensions) – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Column.Name:
Original
Income
Column.Tooltip: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) minus private transfers paid to other households.

Column.Name:
Benefits incl.
Pub. Pen.
Column.Tooltip: Family, education, pensions, disability, health, social assistance, housing and unemployment benefits.

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Table.Title: 2.1.b Mean household income by household type and income components

The table shows the mean household income disaggregated by household type and income components. The last two columns show to what extent benefits and taxes are simulated in Euromod (rather than taken from the inputdata), expressed as the share of simulated benefits/taxes of all benefits/taxes. The last row shows the mean income of the total population (All).

The calculation of the mean incomes is based on non-equivalised household results.

Table.Title: 2.2.a Mean equivalised income by decile groups and income components
Table.Description:
The table shows the mean (individual) equivalised income disaggregated by decile groups and income components. The last two columns show to what extent benefits and taxes are simulated in Euromod (rather than taken from the inputdata), expressed as the share of simulated benefits/taxes of all benefits/taxes. The last two rows show the mean income of the total population (All) and the population at-risk-of-poverty (Poor).

The calculation of the decile groups and the reported mean incomes is based on equivalised income.

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Table.Description:
The table shows the mean (individual) equivalised income disaggregated by household type and income components. The last two columns show to what extent benefits and taxes are simulated in Euromod (rather than taken from the inputdata), expressed as the share of simulated benefits/taxes of all benefits/taxes. The last row shows the mean income of the total population (All).

The calculation of the reported mean incomes is based on equivalised income.

The table shows the mean (individual) equivalised income disaggregated by labour status and income components. The last two columns show to what extent benefits and taxes are simulated in Euromod (rather than taken from the inputdata), expressed as the share of simulated benefits/taxes of all benefits/taxes. The last row shows the mean income of the total population (All).

The calculation of the reported mean incomes is based on equivalised income.

The table shows the mean (individual) equivalised income disaggregated by gender and income components. The last two columns show to what extent benefits and taxes are simulated in Euromod (rather than taken from the inputdata), expressed as the share of simulated benefits/taxes of all benefits/taxes. The last two rows show the mean income of the total population (All) and the population at-risk-of-poverty (Poor).

The calculation of the reported mean incomes is based on equivalised income.

Table.Title: 2.2.e Mean equivalised income by age groups and income components
Table.Description:
The table shows the mean (individual) equivalised income disaggregated by age groups and income components. The last two columns show to what extent benefits and taxes are simulated in Euromod (rather than taken from the inputdata), expressed as the share of simulated benefits/taxes of all benefits/taxes. The last two rows show the mean income of the total population (All) and the population at-risk-of-poverty (Poor).

The calculation of the reported mean incomes is based on equivalised income.

Table.Title: 3.1 Basic Inequality Indices
Table.Description:
The table shows the Gini index and S80/20 indicator for selected income concepts:

·         The comparison of the original income with the original income after taxes shows to what extent taxes contribute to redistribution.

·         The comparison of the original income plus public pensions after taxes with the original income after taxes shows the role of public pensions for redistribution.

·         The comparison of the original income with the disposable income shows the extent of income redistribution performed by the tax-benefit system as a whole (incl. social insurance contributions and benefits beyond public pensions).

The calculated indexes are income-concept-specific. However, the definition of the top and bottom 20% is always based on disposable income.

Column.Name: Gini
Column.Tooltip: Measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

Column.Name: S80/S20
Column.Tooltip: Ratio of total income received top quintile to that received by bottom quintile.

Row.Name: Original Income
Row.Tooltip: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) minus private transfers paid to other households.

Row.Name: Original Income after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Original Income incl. Public Pensions after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Public Pensions – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Disposable Income
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Benefits (incl. Public Pensions) – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Table.Description: The table shows the poverty rate, the poverty gap and the poverty line for the whole population.

Column.Name: Value

Row.Name: At-risk-of-poverty rate
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Row.Name: Median at-risk-of-poverty gap
Row.Tooltip: Difference between the median equivalised disposable income of people at-risk-of-poverty and poverty line, as a percentage of poverty line.

Row.Name: Poverty line (monthly)
Row.Tooltip: 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income.

Table.Title: 4.1 Shares of Income and Income-Components
Table.Subtitle: received/paid by each decile group
Table.Description: The table shows the shares of unequivalised household income and each income component received or paid by each income decile. It answers the question of how much income is concentrated in each income decile and shows who receives the highest share of income support and who pays the highest taxes and social insurance contributions to the welfare state. The last row shows how much income is concentrated at the population at-risk-of-poverty.

Column.Name: Disposable Income
Column.Tooltip: Original income + Benefits (incl. Public Pensions) – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Column.Name: Original Income
Column.Tooltip: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) minus private transfers paid to other households.

Column.Name:
Benefits
incl. Pub. Pen.
Column.Tooltip: Family, education, pensions, disability, health, social assistance, housing and unemployment benefits.

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Table.Title: 4.2.a Household composition - Average Number of individuals by labour status
Table.Description: The table gives background information on the household composition by presenting the average household size of different decile groups and the average number of individuals by labour status. The last row gives the same information for the population at-risk-of-poverty.

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Table.Title: 4.2.b Household composition - Average Number of individuals by age groups
Table.Description: The table gives background information on the household composition by presenting the average household size of different decile groups and the average number of individuals by age groups. The last row gives the same information for the population at-risk-of-poverty.

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Table.Title: 4.3.a Share of population groups in each decile, by labour status
Table.Description: The table gives background information on the share of individuals by labour status in different decile groups.

Table.Title: 4.3.b Share of population groups in each decile by age groups
Table.Description: The table gives background information on the share of individuals by age groups in different decile groups.

Table.Title: 4.4 Decile and Poverty Cut Offs
Table.Description: The table shows the cut-off points of equivalised disposable household income for each decile group as well as the poverty line.

Row.Name: Poverty Line
Row.Tooltip: 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income.

Page.Name: Metadata
Page.Title: Metadata
Page.Description: The table shows information on the execution: run system, dataset, output file name, add-ons and extensions selected, execution start time, execution end time and execution duration.
